children.subject: While this might be the case for some, I think it's worth practicing Leetcode/Cracking the Coding Interview/CS61B. Unless you've just taken 61B, you'll probably want to brush up on the exact type of question format that it's asked in. I know I get nervous, so it gives me confidence to practice like this!

For me less than 10, I am at facebook, and I think leetcode skills are less important than people skills, especially when applying for internship. You get enough knowledge for most interview questions from just 61b.
+1 to teaching helping with interviews - lab assisnting 61a/b could be a great way to improve interview skills

0.

Well-conducted SWE intern interviews are 30% coding and 70% communication in my experience. If you know your data structures and standard libraries you will be good enough for almost all coding stuff.

According to the fulltimers on teams I've interned with, they've often encountered cases where otherwise very talented/smart/hardworking/diligent candidates

1) fail to communicate their solution clearly, either verbally or in code

2) encounter a harder problem, stumble, and run into 1) with their incorrect solution and/or fail to take cues from the interviewer that could point them in the right direction

Doing leetcode alone is not gonna help you with communication. Doing mock interviews or practicing with friends would probably be more beneficial to exercise that. Also I've noticed that teaching has made me a better interviewee- it biases me towards simpler and more easy to understand approaches and makes it second nature to check that my audience (my interviewer or student) is following along.

0-50. Going to be 100% honest, unless you want to play the lottery system and have an outstanding resume it's going to be a tough time applying online. Added to the fact that you are an international student a lot of smaller companies may not want to go through the headaches associated with hiring an international student. You either need to network the hell out of something or develop a specialization that makes you standout. To give my quick experience, I got my first internship after freshman year by converting a URAP position into full time, my second one was due to networking, by my third internship I had developed a specialization and refined it there, fourth internship which I just finished I got hired for my specialization. Not going to say this is ubiquitous across people and I'm sure people are going to comment on how they got aninternship from applying online. However in this process, I never went super try hard on the application process, I never was scrambling at the last minute to get something, I never had to bother with leetcode, and I do have a return offer next year. So just my two cents.

history.content: Hi, all! I'd like to ask for experiences about how many leetcode problems did you practice before landing on an internship? I know that this question definitely not have a universal answer, and it differs from person to person. I definitely don't mean to make anyone more anxious, in contrast, I wish to have a rough estimate of how prepared I am to search for internships (as a rising sophomore). I also wish to sincerely ask about experiences regarding to, is it possible for berkeley undergrad who don't have any internship experience to get a full-time SWE job after graduation? Is it alright to only have one internship experience? I am asking because as an international student, I only have limited time to search jobs in U.S. after graduation; also although I can do fine on academic at berkeley, I feel like real-life job hunting and the skill set for industry is completely different than that taught at school.
history.subject: How many Leetcode problems did you practice before landing on an internship / full time job?

history.content: Hi, all! I'd like to ask for experiences about how many leetcode problems did you practice before landing on an internship? I know that this question definitely not have a universal answer, and it differs from person to person. I definitely don't mean to make anyone more anxious, in contrast, I wish to have a rough estimate of how prepared I am to search for internships (as a rising sophomore). I also wish to sincerely ask about experiences regarding to, is it possible for berkeley undergrad who don't have any internship experience to get a full-time SWE job after graduation? Is it alright to only have one internship experience? I am asking because as an international student, I only have limited time to search jobs in U.S. after graduation, and although I can do well on academic at berkeley, I feel like real-life job hunting and the skill set for industry is completely different than that taught at school. I sometimes feel like at school, I have a "mission" or goal to do well on the academics, and I can; but I must also seek out jobs, but this seem to be like a different route... So I sometimes feel like I am endeavoring for two seperate things...
history.subject: How many leetcode problems did you practice before landing on an internship / full time job?

answers.text: I don't have an internship yet, and I just want to see pull result.
